title: 108_hr1106
content: The "Fremont-Madison Conveyance Act" defines terms like "District" and "Secretary" and involves the conveyance of facilities. The "Fremont-Madison Conveyance Act" requires the Secretary of the Interior to convey water distribution and drainage facilities to the Fremont-Madison Irrigation District in Idaho. If the conveyance is not completed by September 13, 2004, a report must be submitted to Congress explaining the delay. The Secretary will require the District to pay administrative costs for the conveyance and related activities, including environmental review. Additionally, the District must pay the net present value of remaining obligations or $280,000 to the United States. Amounts received will go into the Reclamation Fund. The Secretary will convey the Teton Exchange Wells to the District along with the Idaho Department of Water Resources permit and equipment. The water service contract between the Secretary and the District is extended until all conditions are met. Prior to conveyance, environmental reviews must be completed as per the Memorandum of Agreement. SEC. 6. Prior to conveyance, environmental reviews must be completed as per the Memorandum of Agreement referenced in section 3(a). SEC. 7. The United States shall not be liable for damages arising from the conveyed facilities, except for negligence prior to conveyance. SEC. 8. Water supply to District lands. SEC. 8. Water supply to District lands is increased to reflect current acreage, including lands annexed prior to enactment. Deliveries authorized under existing water storage contracts remain unchanged. SEC. 9. Drought management planning in the Henry's Fork watershed to address all water uses within 18 months. SEC. 10. Effect. SEC. 10. EFFECT. This Act does not affect existing rights of any person or the Shoshone-Bannock Tribes' water rights based on treaties, compacts, or laws. Conveyances under this Act do not impact existing contracts or state laws regarding water use rights.
